seriesStmt.title: Encyclopaedia Britannica: A machine-readable text transcription

availability.p: National Library of Scotland License: CC BY 4.0

listBibl.head: Alternate image sources for this edition:
listBibl.bibl: Hathi Trust, from print source at the University of Wisconsin: vol. 9, pp. 29, 31, 32, 36, 37, 39, 41, 48, 50-55, 57, 59, 62, 63, 66, 67, 69-71, 76, 88; vol. 19 (all).
Hathi Trust, from print souce at the University of Chicago: vol. 10, pp. 7-10; vols. 20, 21 (all).

correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is incidated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding has been done using the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: This release reproduces the text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

prefixDef.p: URIs with the prefix fast: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).
URIs with the prefix lcsh1910: point to subject terms in the volume Subject Headings Used in the Dictionary Catalogues of the Library of Congress, 7 vols., Library of Congress, 1910.
URIs with the prefix ht: point to page images in the Hathi Trust.
URIs with the prefix ia: point to page images in the Internet Archive.
URIs with the prefix nls: point to page images in the National Library of Scotland.

div.p: ANQUETTL, Lewis Peter, a French historian, was born at Paris on the 21st of January 1723. At the age of 17 he entered the congregation of St Genevieve, where he taught theology and literature with ability and success. He afterwards became director of the aeademy at Rheims; and, in 1759, he was appointed prior of the abbey de la Roe, in Anjou. Soon after this he was sent, in the capacity of director, to the college of Senlis. In 1766 he obtained the curacy or priory of Clιateau-Renard, near Montargis, whieh he exehanged, at the commencement of the Revolution, for the curacy of La Villette, in the neighbourhood of Paris. During the reign of terror he was imprisoned at St Lazare. On the establishment of the National Institute, he was elected a member of the seeond elass, and was soon afterwards employed in the office of the minister for foreign affairs. Endowed with a robust constitution, whieh was preserved by a natural equality of temper, and general moderation in diet, Anquetil was capable of very laborious exertions, and is said to have passed ten hours every day regularly in study. When upwards of eighty he still meditated extensive literary undertakings; but he was carried off by death, in the midst of his projects and researches, on the 6th of September 1808, in the 86th year of his age. On. the evening previous to this event, he is reported to have said to one of his friends, “Come and see a man who is dying full of life.”

As an author, Μ. Anquetil does not stand very high in the ranks of literature. He possessed more industry in research than ability or judgment in execution. His style is censurable in many respeets, and he appears to have been almost entirely destitute of the critical discernment and philosophical sagaeity whieh are requisite to form the character of a good historian. The following is a list of his principal works.

1. HistoireCivileetPolitique de la Ville de Reims. 1756-57, 3 vols. 12mo. The history is brought no farther down than 1657: a fourth volume should have been added, but it never appeared. Anquetil is said to have written this work in concert with one Felix de la Salle, and it is, perhaps, the best of all his productions. 2. Almαnaxh de Reims. 1754, 24to 3. ĽEsprit de la Ligue, ou HistoirePolitique des TroublesdeFrancependant les 16 et 17 siècles. 1 /67, 3 vols. 12mo. This work has been frequently reprinted. 4. Intrigue du Cabinet sous Henri 1V.etsous Louis XIII.terminéepar la Fronde, 1780, 4 vols. 12mo. 5. LouisXIV.saCouret leRegent. 1789, 4 vols. 12mo; reprinted in 1794, 5 vols. 12mo. 6. Vie duMaréchalde Villars,écritepar lui-memc,Suiviedu Journal de la Cour de 1724 a 1734. 1,Paris, 1787, 4 vols. 12mo; reprinted in 1792. <7. Précisde ľHistoire Universelle.. 1797,

9 vois. 12mo; reprinted in 1801 and 1807, in 12 vols. 12mo. This work has been translated into English, Spanish, and Italian. 8. Motifsdes Guerres et des Traites de Paix de la France pendant les règnes de Louis XIV., Louis XV., et Louis XVI. 1798, 8vo. 9. Histoire de France' depuis les Gaules jusqu’à la fin de la Monarchie. 1805 et seqq. 14 vols. 12mo. This work was composed in haste, and is of no great value. 10. Noticesurla Vie de Μ. Aη-quetil du Perron. Μ. Anquetil likewise wrote several papers in the Memoirs of the Institute. See Biographie
